716817f-a.text:
Bowling Green: The first public park in Manhattan, north from Steamship Row, (now the site of the Custom House) and between Broadway (left) and Whitehall (right) Streets. The buildings shown on the right, would be at the S.E. corner of Beaver Street, a portion of the present (1937) Produce Exchange site.
1869.
Brown Brothers.

716816f-a.text:
Bowling Green: A park located between Whitehall Street (left) and Broadway (right). This view is south on Broadway, from a point south of Norris Street, and shows across the Green, Nos. 1 to 7 Bowling Green, a row of 4 1/2-story buildings, known as "Steamship Row," because of their occupants' occupation. The buildings on the right, in the order of their appearance are north of, adjoining and at the N.W. corner of Battery Place. The corner building being the Hotel Washington.
1870.
N.Y. Edison Company.

716813f-b.text:
(1)
Bowling Green: A park situated between Broadway (left) and Whitehall Street (right). The view is north from in front of buildings known at this date, as Steamship Row (Nos. 1 to 7 Bowling Green). To-day in 1937, they form the northern side of the Custom House. Intersection shown on the right, is Beaver Street, of which the S.E. corner (present
site of the Produce Exchange) is clearly depicted.
1874.
New York Edison Company.
(2)
The original; No. 1 being an enlargement.
1874.
New York Edison Cowpany.

(1)

716951f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from Stone to Beaver Street's, showing the distinctive building of the New York Produce Exchange, as photographed across Manhattan's first park, Bowling Green. At the right is the row of residences that became "Steamship Row" and was later replaced with the '7. S. Custom House. Above their roofs appears the 8 story Kemble Bldg. on Whitehall Street (continuation of Broadway) from Stone to Bridge Street's. To the left is an eastward perspective on Beaver Street, to include the incomplete New York Cotton Exchange Bldg. (erected 1883-5). Beyond this is the vague buttress of the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge. The photographers vantage point is the Washington Pldg. at No. 1 Iroadway. This photo is an enlargement from a lantern slide.
Circa 1884
Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library

716820f-a.text:
1 to 7 Bowling Green, south side, between Whitehall (left) and State (right) Streets, as viewed southward from Broadway and across the first public park; Bowling Green. To-day (1937) the U.S. Custom House stands here. Shown on the extreme left, is a portion of the Produce Exchange Building.
About 1890-1895.
August Loeffler.
P.S. Sperr Collectlon.

723436f-a.text:
Stone Street (foreground) at the N.E. corner of Broadway (left), showing a northward view across the court like Produce Exchange at the above location. This photograph is taken from the Telephone Building at No. 108-112 Broad Street and shows prominently amongst these office structures, the tower of the Standard Oil Company Building.
August 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716826f-a.text:
Bowling Green, west from Whitehall to State Streets, showing N.P.A. employees removing the Broadway car tracks that at this point encircle the Green. Note on the left the northwestern corner of the U.S. Custom House obscuring a portion of Battery Park with the South Ferry elevated
station therein.
August 25, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

716824f-a.text:
(1)
Bowling Green: A view southward acrows the green, and showing Nos. 1-7 Bowling Green; a row of 4 1'2-story houses, occupied by steamship agents. On the left is Whitehall Street, west side, south to Seuth Ferry.
About 1869.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
A closer view of buildings on the "Row."
1900.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

716825f-b.text:
(1)
Bowling Green, between Whitehall (left) and State (right) Streets, as viewed southward from Broadway. Across the Green is the D.5. Custom House.
June 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Tne same.
July 2, 1937.
P. L. Spewr.

723435f-a.text:
Stone Street, east from Whitehall, to and including Broad Streets, showing on the extreme left, the Produce Exchange Building.
August 6, 1930.
T M3E:.
